adjust.explanation: It replaces `index` in array `list` with the result of `replaceFn(list[i])`.
adjust.failedSpecsReasons: Ramda method accepts an array-like object

all.explanation: It returns `true`, if all members of array `list` returns `true`, when applied as argument to `predicate` function.

allPass.explanation: It returns `true`, if all functions of `predicates` return `true`, when `input` is their argument.
allPass.failedSpecsReasons: Ramda method returns a curried function whose arity matches that of the highest-arity predicate

always.explanation: It returns function that always returns `x`.

and.example:
R.and(true, true); // => true
R.and(false, true); // => false
R.and(true, 'foo'); // => 'foo'

or.example:
R.or(false, true); // => true
R.or(false, false); // => false
R.or(false, 'foo'); // => 'foo'

any.explanation: It returns `true`, if at least one member of `list` returns true, when passed to a `predicate` function.
any.example:
const list = [1, 2, 3]
const predicate = x => x * x > 8
R.any(fn, list)
// => true

append.explanation: It adds element `x` at the end of `list`.

applySpec.notes: The currying in this function works best with functions with 4 arguments or less. (arity of 4)

clamp.explanation:
Restrict a number `input` to be withing `min` and `max` limits.

If `input` is bigger than `max`, then the result is `max`.

If `input` is smaller than `min`, then the result is `min`.

clone.explanation: It creates a deep copy of the `input`, which may contain (nested) Arrays and Objects, Numbers, Strings, Booleans and Dates.
clone.failedSpecsReasons: Rambda method work only with objects and arrays

complement.explanation:
It returns `inverted` version of `origin` function that accept `input` as argument.

The return value of `inverted` is the negative boolean value of `origin(input)`.

cond.explanation:
It takes list with `conditions` and returns a new function `fn` that expects `input` as argument. 

This function will start evaluating the `conditions` in order to find the first winner(order of conditions matter). 

The winner is this condition, which left side returns `true` when `input` is its argument. Then the evaluation of the right side of the winner will be the final result.

If no winner is found, then `fn` returns `undefined`.

converge.explanation: Accepts a converging function and a list of branching functions and returns a new function. When invoked, this new function is applied to some arguments, each branching function is applied to those same arguments. The results of each branching function are passed as arguments to the converging function to produce the return value.

defaultTo.explanation:
It returns `defaultValue`, if all of `inputArguments` are `undefined`, `null` or `NaN`.

Else, it returns the first truthy `inputArguments` instance(from left to right).
defaultTo.example:
// With single input argument
R.defaultTo('foo', 'bar') // => 'bar'
R.defaultTo('foo', undefined) // => 'foo'

// With multiple input arguments
R.defaultTo('foo', undefined, null, NaN) // => 'foo'
R.defaultTo('foo', undefined, 'bar', NaN, 'qux') // => 'bar'
R.defaultTo('foo', undefined, null, NaN, 'quz') // => 'qux'

either.explanation:
It returns a new `predicate` function from `firstPredicate` and `secondPredicate` inputs.

This `predicate` function will return `true`, if any of the two input predicates return `true`.

find.explanation:
It returns the first element of `list` that satisfy the `predicate`.

If there is no such element, it returns `undefined`.

findIndex.explanation:
It returns the index of the first element of `list` satisfying the `predicate` function.

If there is no such element, then `-1` is returned.

findLast.explanation:
It returns the last element of `list` satisfying the `predicate` function.

If there is no such element, then `undefined` is returned.

findLastIndex.explanation:
It returns the index of the last element of `list` satisfying the `predicate` function.

If there is no such element, then `-1` is returned.

groupWith.explanation: It returns separated version of list or string `input`, where separation is done with equality `compareFn` function.

has.failedSpecsReasons: Rambda method does check properties from the prototype chain

hasPath.explanation: It will return true, if `input` object has truthy `path`(calculated with `R.path`).

head.explanation: It returns the first element of list or string `input`.

identical.notes: Values are identical if they reference the same memory. `NaN` is identical to `NaN`; `0` and `-0` are not identical.
identical.explanation:
It returns `true` if its arguments `a` and `b` are identical.

Otherwise, it returns `false`.
identical.example:
const obj = {a: 1};
R.identical(obj, obj); //=> true
R.identical(1, 1); //=> true
R.identical(1, '1'); //=> false
R.identical([], []); //=> false
R.identical(0, -0); //=> false
R.identical(NaN, NaN); //=> true

ifElse.explanation:
It expects `condition`, `onTrue` and `onFalse` functions as inputs and it returns a new function with example name of `fn`. 

When `fn`` is called with `input` argument, it will return either `onTrue(input)` or `onFalse(input)` depending on `condition(input)` evaluation.

includes.explanation:
If `input` is string, then this method work as native `String.includes`.

If `input` is array, then `R.equals` is used to define if `valueToFind` belongs to the list.

indexBy.explanation:
It generates object with properties provided by `condition` and values provided by `list` array.

If `condition` is a function, then all list members are passed through it.

If `condition` is a string, then all list members are passed through `R.path(condition)`.

indexOf.explanation:
It returns the index of the first element of `list` equals to `valueToFind`.

If there is no such element, it returns `-1`.

init.explanation: It returns all but the last element of list or string `input`.

intersection.explanation: It loops throw `listA` and `listB` and returns the intersection of the two according to `R.equals`.

intersperse.explanation: It adds a `separator` between members of `list`.

is.explanation: It returns `true` if `x` is instance of `targetPrototype`.

isNil.explanation: It returns `true` if `x` is either `null` or `undefined`.

join.explanation: It returns a string of all `list` instances joined with a `glue`.

keys.explanation: It applies `Object.keys` over `x` and returns its keys.

last.explanation: It returns the last element of `input`, as the `input` can be either a string or an array.

lastIndexOf.explanation:
It returns the last index of `target` in `list` array.

`R.equals` is used to determine equality between `target` and members of `list`.

If there is no such index, then `-1` is returned.

length.explanation: It returns the `length` property of list or string `input`.
length.failedSpecsReasons: Ramda method supports object with `length` method

lens.explanation:
It returns a `lens` for the given `getter` and `setter` functions. 

The `getter` **gets** the value of the focus; the `setter` **sets** the value of the focus. 

The setter should not mutate the data structure.

lensIndex.explanation: It returns a lens that focuses on specified `index`.
lensIndex.example:
const list = ['a', 'b', 'c']
const headLens = R.lensIndex(0)

R.view(headLens, list) // => 'a'
R.set(headLens, 'x', list) // => ['x', 'b', 'c']
R.over(headLens, R.toUpper, list) // => ['A', 'b', 'c']

lensProp.explanation: It returns a lens that focuses on specified property `prop`.

over.explanation: It returns a copied **Object** or **Array** with modified value received by applying function `fn` to `lens` focus.

set.explanation: It returns a copied **Object** or **Array** with modified `lens` focus set to `replacer` value.

view.explanation: It returns the value of `lens` focus over `target` object.

map.notes: Unlike Ramda's `map`, here property and input object are passed as arguments to `fn`, when `iterable` is an object.

match.explanation: Curried version of `String.prototype.match` which returns empty array, when there is no match.

mathMod.notes: Explanation is taken from `Ramda` documentation site.
mathMod.explanation: `R.mathMod` behaves like the modulo operator should mathematically, unlike the `%` operator (and by extension, `R.modulo`). So while `-17 % 5` is `-2`, `mathMod(-17, 5)` is `3`.
mathMod.example:
const result = [
  R.mathMod(-17, 5),
  R.mathMod(17, 5),
  R.mathMod(17, -5),  
  R.mathMod(17, 0)   
]
// => [3, 2, NaN, NaN]

max.explanation: It returns the greater value between `x` and `y`.

maxBy.explanation: It returns the greater value between `x` and `y` according to `compareFn` function.

mean.explanation: It returns the mean value of `list` input.

median.explanation: It returns the median value of `list` input.

merge.explanation: It creates a copy of `target` object with overidden `newProps` properties.

mergeAll.explanation: It merges all objects of `list` array sequentially and returns the result.

mergeDeepRight.explanation:
Creates a new object with the own properties of the first object merged with the own properties of the second object. If a key exists in both objects:

  - and both values are objects, the two values will be recursively merged
  - otherwise the value from the second object will be used.

mergeLeft.explanation: Same as `R.merge`, but in opposite direction.

min.explanation: It returns the lesser value between `x` and `y`.

minBy.explanation: It returns the lesser value between `x` and `y` according to `compareFn` function.

not.explanation: It returns a boolean negated version of `input`.

nth.example:
const list = [1, 2, 3]
const str = 'foo'

const result = [
  R.nth(2, list),
  R.nth(6, list),
  R.nth(0, str),
]
// => [3, undefined, 'f']

once.explanation: It returns a function, which invokes only once `fn` function.

omit.notes: When using this method with `TypeScript`, it is much easier to pass `propsToOmit` as an array. If passing a string, you will need to explicitly declare the output type.

partial.explanation:
It is very similar to `R.curry`, but you can pass initial arguments when you create the curried function.

`R.partial` will keep returning a function until all the arguments that the function `fn` expects are passed.
The name comes from the fact that you partially inject the inputs.

partition.explanation: It will return array of two objects/arrays according to `predicate` function. The first member holds all instanses of `input` that pass the `predicate` function, while the second member - those who doesn't.

If `pathToSearch` is `'a.b'` then it will return `1` if `obj` is `{a:{b:1}}`.

It will return `undefined`, if such path is not found.

pathEq.explanation:
It returns `true` if `pathToSearch` of `input` object is equal to `target` value.

`pathToSearch` is passed to `R.path`, which means that it can be either a string or an array. Also equality between `target` and the found value is determined by `R.equals`.

paths.explanation:
It loops over members of `pathsToSearch` as `singlePath` and returns the array produced by `R.path(singlePath, obj)`.

Because it calls `R.path`, then `singlePath` can be either string or a list.

pick.explanation:
It returns a partial copy of an `input` containing only `propsToPick` properties.

`input` can be either an object or an array.

String anotation of `propsToPick` is one of the differences between `Rambda` and `Ramda`.
pick.example:
const obj = {
  a : 1,
  b : false,
  foo: 'cherry'
}
const list = [1, 2, 3, 4]
const propsToPick = 'a,foo'
const propsToPickList = ['a', 'foo']

const result = [
  R.pick(propsToPick, obj),
  R.pick(propsToPickList, obj),
  R.pick('a,bar', obj),
  R.pick('bar', obj),
  R.pick([0, 3], list),
  R.pick('0,3', list),
]

const expected = [
  {a:1, foo: 'cherry'},
  {a:1, foo: 'cherry'},
  {a:1},
  {},
  [1,4],
  [1,4]
]
// => `result` is equal to `expected`

pipe.failedSpecsReasons: Ramda method passes context to functions | Rambda composed functions have no length

pluck.explanation: It returns list of the values of `property` taken from the all objects inside `list`.
pluck.example:
const list = [{a: 1}, {a: 2}, {b: 3}]
const property = 'a'

R.pluck(list, property) 
// => [1, 2]

reverse.explanation: It returns a reversed copy of list or string `input`.

slice.example:
const list = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
const str = 'FOO_BAR'
const from = 1
const to = 4

const result = [
  R.slice(str, to, list),
  R.slice(from, to, list)
]
// => ['OO_', [1, 2, 3]]

sort.explanation: It returns copy of `list` sorted by `sortFn` function.

sortBy.notes: `sortFn` function must return a value to compare.

startsWith.notes: It doesn't work with arrays unlike its corresponding **Ramda** method.

subtract.example:
const x = 3
const y = 1

R.subtract(x, y) 
// => 2

symmetricDifference.notes: `R.equals` is used to determine equality, i.e. it can be safely used with list of objects.
symmetricDifference.explanation: It returns a merged list of `x` and `y` with all equal elements removed.

tail.explanation: It returns all but the first element of `input`.

take.explanation: It returns the first `howMany` elements of `input`.

takeLast.explanation: It returns the last `howMany` elements of `input`.

tap.explanation:
It applies function `fn` to input `x` and returns `x`. 

One use case is debuging in the middle of `R.compose`.
tap.example:
const list = [1, 2, 3]

R.compose(
  R.map(x => x * 2)
  R.tap(console.log),
  R.filter(x => x > 1)
)(list)
// => `2` and `3` will be logged
tap.failedSpecsReasons: Ramda method can act as a transducer

times.explanation:
It returns the result of applying function `fn` over members of range array.

The range array includes numbers between `0` and `howMany`(exclusive).
times.example:
const fn = x => x * 2
const howMany = 5

R.times(fn, howMany)
//=> [0, 2, 4, 6, 8]

toPairs.explanation: It transforms an object to a list.

trim.failedSpecsReasons: Ramda method trims all ES5 whitespace

tryCatch.explanation: It returns function that runs `fn` in `try/catch` block. If there was an error, then `fallback` is used to return the result. Note that `fn` can be value or asynchronous/synchronous function(unlike `Ramda` where fallback can only be a synchronous function).

type.explanation: It accepts any input and it returns its type.
type.example:
R.type(() => {}) // => 'Function'
R.type(async () => {}) // => 'Async'
R.type([]) // => 'Array'
R.type({}) // => 'Object'
R.type('foo') // => 'String'
R.type(1) // => 'Number'
R.type(true) // => 'Boolean'
R.type(null) // => 'Null'
R.type(/[A-z]/) // => 'RegExp'
R.type('foo'*1) // => 'NaN'

const delay = ms => new Promise(resolve => {
  setTimeout(function () {
    resolve()
  }, ms)
})
R.type(delay) // => 'Promise'
type.failedSpecsReasons: Ramda method returns 'Number' type to NaN input, while Rambda method returns 'NaN'

union.explanation:
It takes two lists and return a new list containing a merger of both list with removed duplicates. 

`R.equals` is used to compare for duplication, which means that it can be safely used with array of objects.

uniq.explanation: It returns a new array containing only one copy of each element of `list`.
uniq.failedSpecsReasons: Ramda method pass to `uniq` method | Ramda method uses reference equality for functions

uniqWith.explanation: It returns a new array containing only one copy of each element in `list` according to boolean returning function `uniqFn`.
uniqWith.example:
const list = [
  {id: 0, title:'foo'},
  {id: 1, title:'bar'},
  {id: 2, title:'baz'},
  {id: 3, title:'foo'},
  {id: 4, title:'bar'},
]

const expected = [
  {id: 0, title:'foo'},
  {id: 1, title:'bar'},
  {id: 2, title:'baz'},
]

const uniqFn = (x,y) => x.title === y.title

const result = R.uniqWith(uniqFn, list)
// => `result` is equal to `expected`

unless.explanation:
The method returns function that will be called with argument `input`.

If `predicate(input)` returns `false`, then the end result will be the outcome of `whenFalse(input)`.

In the other case, the final output will be the `input` itself.

zip.explanation:
It will return a new array containing tuples of equally positions items from both `x` and `y` lists. 

The returned list will be truncated to match the length of the shortest supplied list.

zipObj.explanation: It will return a new object with keys of `keys` array and values of `values` array.

props.explanation: It takes list with properties `propsToPick` and returns a list with property values in `obj`.

splitWhen.explanation:
It splits `list` to two arrays according to a `predicate` function. 

The first array contains all members of `list` before `predicate` returns `true`.

evolve.notes: Error handling of this method differs between Ramda and Rambda. Ramda for some wrong inputs returns result and for other - it returns one of the inputs. Rambda simply throws when inputs are not correct. Full details for this mismatch are listed in `source/_snapshots/evolve.spec.js.snap` file.
evolve.explanation: It takes object or array of functions as set of rules. These `rules` are applied to the `iterable` input to produce the result.
